title: Tuscan typeface
content:
I was digging through some old Type ID threads and saw this typeface that donshonttype had posted. Does anyone know what typeface this is or what it is derived from? I suppose donshonttype would know best.

The base font for this lettering is CastleType's Latin CT, and uses a blend of the condensed width

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114251im_/http:/typophile.com/files/LatinCTCondAsClot_5953.gif)
 and regular width 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114251im_/http:/typophile.com/files/LatinCTAsClot_6653.gif)
  
CastleType's products are well make and worthy of purchase.  
Through an oversight I did not mention the foundry in my earlier post. Here is a link to the fonts [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-ct/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114251/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-ct/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/latin-ct/")  
The spurs are added to demonstrate the ease of making something similar to the "Bowery" style of lettering that Nike has used for its clothing [http://typophile.com/node/103278](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114251/http:/typophile.com/node/103278 "http://typophile.com/node/103278")  
Have fun making your own version.  
Don
Great, thanks donshottype. Looks like you did a fair bit of tweaking to make your sample. Nice work!

Thank you Tylor for the kudos.  
The result seems to be successful as a Latinate serif with spurs, but I find the spiky tone of the resulting design to be somewhat aggressive and appropriate mainly for bikers, angry rock bands and the ilk.  
When the same spurs are used on a font with a softer serif treatment, such as a plush fish tail Tuscan, the effect is more of an ornamented space filler that producdes a font that has a tone suitable for applications from stock certificates to restaurant menus. The spurs might also work for a similar wide range of applications if it is used on font with a Clarendon or thick slab serif.  
Don

For examples of the use of median spurs on a Clarendon and on a plush fish tail Tuscan see [http://www.typophile.com/node/117209](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114251/http:/www.typophile.com/node/117209 "http://www.typophile.com/node/117209")  
Don

Thanks Don. I'm actually quite intrigued by the sharp angular serif typefaces found in Latin CT and an example from the last link you posted (Dan X. Solo's Olympian). I think they would make good candidates for a spur transplant. What would be some good keywords to search for those kind of typefaces?
